title: Manchester United transfer news and rumours: Red Devils to miss out on Brazilian starlet Thiago Maia?
text:

Brazilian starlet Thiago Maia has dealt Manchester United a transfer blow by saying he would prefer a move to Paris Saint-Germain should he make the switch to Europe. 
The 19-year-old has made a name for himself with Santos and is on United's radar, according to Calciomercato. 
But, in an interview with Lance, Maia revealed he's keen on a switch to the French champions. 
"If I had a chance to go to Europe, I would move to PSG," he said. "Everybody has his own dreams, but I like their style. People want to leave dreams of other people and that’s bad. 
"The structure of the club, the country and the city: I love everything related to PSG. That said, I’d also consider moves to Barcelona or Real Madrid because they are big clubs. 
"I have a dream. I want to play for a big club and I hope that I will do that one day." Willian: United tried to sign me Willian has revealed United tried to sign him (Photo: AFP) 
Willian admits former Chelsea boss Jose Mourinho was interested in taking him to Manchester United last summer. 
The Brazilian was his side's player of the year last term but has failed to nail down a regular starting spot under Antonio Conte. 
Pedro has shone for the Premier League leaders in his absence but Willian insists he is happy at Stamford Bridge, writes Mirror Football's Liam Prenderville. 
He may have followed his former boss to Old Trafford though, if Mourinho had got his way. 
"There was interest, yes. It was from Manchester United, because Mourinho is there too," he told Globo Esporte. Carrick: Top four is nothing to shout about Carrick has opened up on United's targets (Photo: Daily Mirror / Andy Stenning) 
Michael Carrick insists no-one at Manchester United will be celebrating if they secure a top-four finish this season. 
Winning is still all that matters at United, even if their last Premier League title triumph came four years ago in Sir Alex Ferguson’s farewell season, writes Mirror Football's David McDonnell. 
For midfielder Carrick , a five-time title-winner with the Old Trafford giants, the frustration at not adding to that haul will be not be soothed by the consolation prize of a Champions League spot. 
“It’s not something we’d celebrate, if we finished third, fourth or even second,” said the 35-year-old. 
“You only celebrate when you win, but the Champions League is a big part of this club. It’s where you want to play, it’s where the best players want to play, 
“So in terms of attracting players and all that type of stuff, the club is geared up for that, of course it is, but you can only celebrate winning, really, and finishing top.” Read More
